segments.text: R.D.
Brown.
Dr. Billy Tremere has asked me to give a brief rundown on my background before reflecting on my association with Dr. U.E.
Mourning.
I grew up on a farm in Callahan County near Putnam, Texas, which is 35 miles east of Abilene.
Our county is a farming and ranching economy
with limited oil and gas production.
My family consisted of my parents, one brother, and one sister, both younger than I.
My parents were hardworking, quality people who believed in teaching their children to work and be productive.
We were given regular test at a early age to perform.
With the understanding that these duties were a must and some.
Form of punishment.
Would result if these duties.
Weren't carried out.
They always compliment us on on a job well done.
We were a happy family due to the quality of our parents.
Study and education.
Was it must?
And we knew the reason why.
They impressed us with the idea that a college education was necessary in order to make the most of our opportunities in life.
I graduated from high school in 1935.
The Great Depression was in full bloom and the family funds were not available at that time to assist me in college.
My dad asked me to stay and help him with reducing the family debt.
For three years I worked on the family farms and on the
on community farms and ranches and in the oil fields of West Texas.
With the family debt under control, I enrolled at A&M in pre-veterinary medicine.
In September of 38, I was assigned to A Company Infantry Corps Cadets.
Texas A&M College
The core cadets.
Hazing and life in general.
Was a different ball game for me.
I learned to take the hazing.
And I enjoyed all forms.
Of college life from the first day on.
The discipline was great.
Fish and sophomores had better be in their rooms studying at 7 PM.
We were given a short time, about two days to remember.
The names of our.
Organization upperclassmen.
After the grace period.
Should you not remember the upperclassmen name?
He would spell it out on your butt.
with one before board, which every upperclassman had at least one.
This procedure was effective in name recall.
Usually better study habits were formed early on in college and under this environment.
They were always upperclassmen available for at least minor tutoring and other study help and advice.
I am glad that I had the opportunity to go to A&M and be in the Corps of Cadets.
After getting adjusted to college life my freshman year, I felt like I was ready to enter the School of Veterinary Medicine.
Uh, with any without any apprehension.
I was a little bit surprised and that anatomy and physiology were so difficult.
But managed to survive.
I had to study hard.
But got by and stayed in school.
Had some great teachers during those years.
to name a few, Dr. Lang, Eads, Burns, Leonard, Dunn, Miliff, Armstead, and Turk, to name a few.
I got by those three years in pretty good shape, and at the end of the spring 42 semesters, I had received a ROTC infantry commission,
And reported for active duty a few weeks later.
At Camp Walters near Middle Wells, TX.
An infantry replacement training center.
I have trained bases there for six months.
I was then transferred to Puerto Rico.
Arriving there 3rd January 43.
And assigned to infantry troops there.
Didn't make it back to the.
The States until April 6th, 46 without firing a shot for record.
After.
Receiving my discharge at Fort Sam.
I joined my parents at home.
And stayed.
Until.
June of 40.
6 and return.
to A&M to complete my last two semesters in the School of Veterinary Medicine.
I was surprised to see so many of my old profs still around.
Also, there were many of my former classmates and friends back to finish their formal education.
Time passed in a hurry and graduation was at hand.
The last week of the semester was a busy one.
We took some final examinations, the state board, and attended a TVMA convention in Houston.
I skipped graduation ceremonies and headed for home.
My license
and diploma caught up with me later.
I found a temporary job in Abilene at a mixed practice.
After spending six weeks in the mixed practice in Abilene, I accepted a job with
Dr. U.E.
Morney at the Alamo Dog and Cat Hospital in San Antonio.
I reported for duty on March 12, 1947.
One of my former classmates, Dr. Richard Culpepper, had been with Dr. Morney since late 1943.
Dr. Morney was born November the 1st, 1882, grew up on a farm in Kansas, was graduated from Kansas City Veterinary College in 1912 at the age of 29.
I'm not sure what his employment was immediately after graduation, but eventually
became associated with a biological company that produced serums and Black Lake vaccines.
About sometime in 1916.
And he moved to San Antonio to establish a branch of his biological firm.
And set up shop.
At 1600 Pleasanton Rd.
This business later closed because of lack of revenue and Dr. Marnie ended up with the land and the buildings.
He remodeled the buildings and established an exclusive small animal practice in 1922.
Apparently the practice was an immediate success
He had an ambulance service, hospital facilities, laboratory, and also he had an ambulance service that would pick up a small animal anywhere in the city for a small fee.
He had an office hour from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m., six days a week.
a staff available on Sundays and holidays for emergency, for emergency services.
The practice remained a small animal only until the early 30s, and due to the depression economics, it became a mixed practice and remained
So until the mid 50s.
At that time.
The practice again became small animal only.
And talking to Richard before.
Reporting for duty the first day.
I learned that Doctor morning that not.
Do any practice?
Or any work of any kind.
But be assured he knew what.
What's going on around the practice?
Miss Marty was in charge of the bookkeeping.
And supervising supervise the office.
In a highly efficient manner.
The first morning on the job.
About mid morning.
I was being briefed in the business office.
On office procedures when Doctor morning made his appearance.
Is a. Attire was something I hadn't.
Quite expected.
He had owner.
A gambler type celluloid visor.
Addressed in pajamas.
A bathrobe.
And rubber boots.
This is why this was his usual attire when he made his appearance.
In the mornings.
Sometimes he had substitute the.
A long white lab coat for the bathrobe.
To say that Dr. Morney was frugal would be the understatement of the century.
A few times I've been with him in a cafe, he would order a child's plate.
When refused, he may or may not order anything else.
If he did order, he asked for separate checks
He paid for his meal and I paid for mine.
There were.
Drugs.
That he and supplies that he would not purchase.
For the practice.
His anesthetic of choices.
Excuse me, his anesthetic of choice was.
chloral hydrate or ether or chloroform.
Take your pick.
Richard and I purchased Nemitol, adhesive tape, splint supplies and numerous other items for use in the hospital out of our funds.
He.
He prepared his own small animal ration.
Which consisted of fresh horse meat.
Fresh vegetable.
Such as cabbage, carrots, potatoes, spinach, lettuce and so forth.
And wheat brand was added for book.
One of the one of the employees was designated as chef.
He prepared the ration by cutting up the ingredients, mixing, and cooking the mixture in an old-fashioned black wash pot on a wood fire.
He made enough to last several days and stored it in a walk-in freezer.
These were a few examples of Dr. Morningford's
but he was not all bad.
He had many good qualities.
He was completely honest, a good citizen, and in his own way, a good professional person.
He was very good to his veterinarian and backed him in every way he could.
He belonged to the Veterinary Medical Association of Bexar County, TVMA, and the AVMA.
He'd been president of the local association and TVMA and had served on numerous committees in the AVMA.
He encouraged his
his DVMs to become active in association affairs and pay their dues in the three associations.
He attended many of the national association AVMA meetings, conventions, also most of the Texas meetings,
and just about all of the Bexar County meetings.
Sometime during the fall of 47, Dr. Morney informed Richard and I that he was planning on retiring at an early date.
Should we be interested in purchasing the practice and all the property involved,
So we indicated and he'd get back to us with a contract in a very short time.
We told him we were interested and within a few days he had the contract.
It seemed like the national debt to us at the time.
But we realized it was a.
It was very reasonable and so.
We shook hands with him.
And and made the deal.

And on January the 1st of 48, Richard and I became the new owners of the Alamo Dog and Cat Cat Hospital and Doctor and Miss Morning finished moving to their home recently purchased in our neighborhood.
He didn't stay away too long as he was back the next day for a visit.
And it so happened that he was back each day for as long as he lived.
That is each work day when he was in town.
The 1959 AVM a convention was to be held in Kansas City, Missouri.
And Doctor morning wasn't about to miss being there since it was close to his old Kansas home.
And near his alma mater.
The Kansas City Veterinary College.
KCVC had been.
Close.
But there were a lot of his old classmates and friends still located nearby.
And he was anxious to see him.
He came by the hospital before he left.
It was very evident that he wasn't feeling well.
He admitted he was feeling punk, but as soon as he got on the road, he'd get on the road.
Well, he'd he'd feel alright.
He left San Antone the next day by car against the advice.
Of his position.
And against the wishes.
Of mid morning.
but he was intent on going and told her that he'd make it all right.
By the time they arrived in Kansas City and checked in a hotel, his condition had worsened and it was termed very serious.
After a brief exam,
by the hotel physician.
He was sent by ambulance to Kansas City Hospital.
Where diffused peritonitis was diagnosed.
And.
Was caused by duodenal.
Ruptured ulcer.
Exploratory surgery was performed.
At once.
But to no avail as he died.
24 hours later.
Post surgery.
He was returned.
Home.
He had an appropriate.
Funeral.
In his church.
The Holland L Baptist Church.
He had 8 pallbearers, all veterinarians.
His funeral was well attended.
And with.
Many veterinarians in attendance.
He was buried at in Mission Park South.
which is 2 12 miles from the hospital, veterinary hospital, that he loves so well.
The inscription on his grave marker reads as simple, Erd Eli Morney, DVM, November 1, 1882, dash 8, or beg your pardon,
August 24.
He is still being missed.
Dr Gerald Parker.
A former classmate of ours.
Joined our partnership.
And practice.
In October of 48.
He brought with him some much needed professional help, expertise and stability.
With him in the partnership, we were able to expand our professional operations.
Also, we were able to pay Dr. Morney off in six and a half years after we took over.
In the latter part of May 64,
The partnership purchased the Highland Animal Hospital.
I was designated to operate the hospital.
We moved in June 1, 64, and took over the practice.
We sold the practice to the new owner, and he took over February 1, 86.
I retired from active practice on that date.
In 1967, the partnership built the Colony North Animal Hospital.
Dr. Richard opened the practice in late 67.
He had had a heart attack in 64 but recovered well and was able to be back on duty in about two months.
He did well until late 69.
His condition worsened and he had his second heart attack.
Had a very slow recovery time.
Should not have been back.
To work.
But insisted.
That he worked.
He had his third and last heart attack in the early morning hours and died on May.
15th at home.
His funeral was held in his Episcopal Church.
To a standing room only clock crowd.
With just about ever DVM in the city attended.
His.
Passing was a great blow to all of us.
He had, but he had the hospital affairs in good order, which made the transition.
An easy one.
One of our associates was designated to operate.
The hospital until Gerald could take over.
In October.
Oh 72.
Gerald still operating the hospital at this time, but the time doctor that lofts.
A special kind of doctor is published.
He should be well retired.
Someone.
Should give him a.
A medal.
or some kind of award for putting up with me these 42 years.
This concludes my part of the dissertation.
Thank you.
Also, I would taken a course in speaking.
Into a cassette recorder.
But I enjoyed reflecting.
All my association with Doctor Morney.
He was truly.
A unique individual.
There was only one pattern.
And there's never been another liking.
